body: Two gunmen held up the Quality Corner Stamp and Coin store in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn yesterday evening and made off with $100,000 in rare coins, the police said. At first the police thought that that a customer had been kidnapped from the store, at 2601 Avenue U, but this proved to be incorrect. The police later concluded that the

A 24-year-old man who worked at his father's Brooklyn funeral parlor was shot to death gangland style yesterday morning as he left work for a coffee break, the police said. The victim, Charles Guarino of 274 Avenue X in the Sheepshead Bay section, was shot in the head eight times by two or three gunmen wearing ski masks, according to Sgt. Ed Burns,
title: Brooklyn Man Is Slain In Gang-Style Shooting

body: More than 50 students and teachers at Sheepshead Bay High School in Brooklyn gathered in a basement classroom yesterday afternoon, drawn together by anger and frustration at the assault on a favorite teacher over the weekend. The teacher, Christopher King, 35 years old, is in Long Island College Hospital with a bullet wound in his abdomen. Hospital
title: STUDENTS AND STAFF FLARE AT WOUNDING OF TEACHER

body: A Brooklyn teacher was shot in the abdomen early yesterday while riding the subway when he resisted at least four teen-agers who were trying to steal his sheepskin coat at gunpoint, the Transit Authority police said. The teacher, Christopher King, 35 years old, was taken to Long Island College Hospital. He was listed early this morning in critical
title: Brooklyn Teacher Shot In Robbery on Subway

body: James Madison High School of Brooklyn won its second Public Schools Athletic Association B Division title with a 36-8 victory over previously undefeated Far Rockaway. Madison, which lost two of its first three games this season, finished with seven straight victories. The Golden Knights, who last won the title in 1977, will play Maria Regina of the
title: JOHN ADAMS AND MADISON CAPTURE P.S.A.L. TITLES

body: Bayside High School of Queens, which had won the Public Schools Athletic League Division A the last three years, was eliminated in the semifinal round yesterday, 22-13, by undefeated Susan Wagner. Wagner will play for the championship against Adams, the Queens regular-season champion, which topped Lehman of the Bronx, 33-6, in another semifinal in
title: Wagner, Adams Gain

body: A police officer was accidentally shot in the left leg by his partner yesterday as the two chased four teen-agers suspected of stealing a car in Brooklyn, the police said. The wounded officer was identified as Timothy Barry of the 60th Precinct in the Coney Island section. He suffered a superficial leg wound when his partner, Joseph Revello,
title: Brooklyn Officer Slightly Hurt When Partner's Gun Goes Off

body: All four of yesterday's scheduled Public Schools Athletic League football semifinals were postponed by rain or wet ground and will be played today. Bayside (5-2) of Queens, the defending A Division champion and winner of the last three city titles, will play at Susan Wagner (7-0), the Staten Island champion, at 1 P.M. today. Lehman (6-1), the Bronx
title: City Playoffs Postponed

body: Adams, Susan Wagner, Lehman and Bayside, the latter two scoring upsets, were victorious in the quarterfinals of the Public Schools Athletic League A Division playoffs. Adams defeated New Dorp, 40-6, while Susan Wagner was a 30-6 winner over Kennedy. Lehman rallied in the final quarter to oust Midwood by 13-6. Bayside, winner of the last three
title: ADAMS, WAGNER, LEHMAN AND BAYSIDE ADVANCED

body: The Governor of New York State walked down Fifth Avenue, on his way to see his wife. At 52d Street he entered the Olympic Tower, walking through its mirrored atrium to 51st Street, and then to the Helmsley Palace Hotel. ''I like things government didn't build,'' he said. He was buffeted by messengers and businessmen on their way to somewhere; only
title: ABOUT NEW YORK

body: Halloween was marked with caution and restraint yesterday as thousands of families in the New York metropolitan area chose costume contests, parades and private parties over trick or treating. With about 50 incidents of contaminated candy, cakes or soda reported in the past few days in the region, many parents sought to curb the traditional
title: CAUTION CAN'T MASK HOLIDAY'S TRUE FACE: HALLOWEEN'S A PARTY

body: Two gunmen entered a Brooklyn pharmacy yesterday and briefly held two employees prisoner before collapsing from prescription drugs they took off shelves and consumed, the police said. The gunmen, who were not immediately identified, were taken unconscious to Coney Island Hospital where their condition was critical, the police said. The gunmen
title: THE CITY; Pharmacy's Wares Subdue 2 Gunmen

body: AT the turn of the century, Sheepshead Bay was a favored resort of the rich. Most came for its race track, its fine seafood restaurants and the s alubrious sea breezes that blew in from the Atlantic. Lillian Russell, Diamond Jim Brady and Lillie Langtry were among t he famous folk who frequented Sheepshead Bay, and they were often s een strolling
title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: SHEEPSHEAD BAY

body: After being stung by a 15-yard first-period field goal by Steve Sharpe, Jefferson roared back to down Lafayette, 36-11, and knock the Redmen from the ranks of the undefeated in the Brooklyn A-Division battle for first place. Ricky Johnson, a 5-foot-10-inch, 190-pound junior fullback, was a key figure in the rout for Jefferson. He ran for a career
title: JEFFERSON DEFEATS LAFAYETTE

body: The game was supposed to start at noon, and both teams were assembled at the Boys & Girls High School field in Brooklyn. There was only one element missing - the mandatory doctor. So after two hours of waiting, it became a forfeit, Sheepshead Bay over Boys & Girls by the unusual score of 1-0. ''The home team is responsible for making the
title: Lack of Doctor Brings Forfeit

body: The Second Degree I f it's ever too late, it hasn't caught up with Melvin M. Hurwitz of Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn, who works in Manhattan as deputy executive director of the New York State Insurance Fund. A former insurance broker, he is a past commander of the Brooklyn and the New York State Jewish War Veterans. Mr. Hurwitz, who took his first
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: TO make his point, Morris Gartenstein reached into the animal world.' 'It's like you're holding a tiger by the tail,'' he said. ''You c an't let it go and you can't pull it back.'' The tiger is a piece of vacant land behind a fence at East 29th Street and Avenue J in the Midwood section of Brooklyn. The Gartenstein family, builders mainly in the
title: SPOT BUILDER IS TREADING WATER

body: Darnell Ethridge of John F. Kennedy High in the Bronx, is almost certain to become a 1,000-yard rusher before the end of the season, but while the DeWitt Clinton defense was keying on him yesterday, his teammate, Vernon Parker, was doing most of the damage as the Knights shut out the Governors, 28-0. The Governors held Ethridge to 42 yards rushing,
title: PARKER OF KENNEDY PLAYS THE KEY ROLE IN ROUT OF CLINTON

body: 1 Margate, N.J.:There are weakfish along the shore in 65 feet of water from Atlantic City to Cape May. Bluefish are mixed with them. Offshore angling for albacore and bonito has improved. Barnegat, N.J.: Large and small weakfish are against the beach; fluke are three miles off; offshore anglers are catching mako sharks; longfin tuna and albacore
title: Weakfish and Blues Are Running

body: Bluefish of all sizes offshore. Albacore and bonito have been sporadic. Early this week, there were some dazzling catches of longfin tuna. One charter boat, the Slammer, brought in 52 of the fish, over a ton, after a day on the edge of Wilmington Canyon. Barnegat, N.J.: Plenty of bluefish over Barnegat Ridge; good catches of longfin tuna over
title: Blues, Flounder and Porgies Are Running 1

title: CITY VOTE FOR TOP STATE OFFICES BY ASSEMBLY DISTRICTS; DEMOCRATIC REPUBLICAN GOVERNOR GOVERNOR

body: Except for a tree in its small entrance courtyard that rises nearly to the roof, there appears to be nothing outstanding about the newly renovated, four-story apartment building at 1554 Ocean Avenue in Brooklyn's Midwood neighborhood. It seems just one of the many residential apartment houses that line the five-mile thoroughfare from Park Slope
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; BROOKLYN BUILDING IS RENOVATED UNDER CITY PROGRAM

body: A visual feast will unfold in New York Harbor tomorrow as a fleet of some 200 yachts, the largest turnout in the nine-year history of the Governor's Cup race, crosses the starting line off the Battery beginning at 11 A.M. Unlike most yacht races, which take place well offshore and out of sight, this 16-mile competition takes the fleet through the
title: THE BIG YACHT RACE THAT EVERYONE CAN SEE

body: EACH fall, do-it-yourselfers turn to continuing education centers around town for how-to workshops in home repairs and renovations. Registration is under way at the institutions in the following sampling. Most classes are held weekday evenings or Saturdays; some at the New School for Social Research are in the early afternoon. To register for
title: COURSES IN HOME MAINTENANCE FOR DO-IT-YOURSELFERS

body: Margate, N.J.: Offshore catches of large bluefish continue, and a few Atlantic bonito are mixed with the blues. Yellowfin and bigeye tuna and white and blue marlin have been good in Wilmington Canyon. A most infrequent visitor this far north, an 88-pound wahoo, was caught recently. Barnegat, N.J.: Hudson Canyon anglers are boating bigeye, yellowfin
title: Bluefish and Tuna Running in Local Waters

body: EARLY last week, a delegation of five tenants from a three-building c omplex on St. Johns Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn wenti nto a local office of the Department of Housing Preservation and D evelopment to meet their new landlord: New York City. Their 50-unit complex was seized on Aug. 13 by the city in the first phase of a
title: NEW LAW REDUCES BROOKLYN TAX FORECLOSURES

body: 1. MARGATE, N.J.: Offshore catches of large bluefish continue and some smaller blues are mixed with them. Atlantic bonito have appeared along the beach. Fluke fishing good two miles offshore. Barnegat, N.J.: Bluefish plentiful; weakfish along the beach and in bay. Offshore over Hudson Canyon, yellowfin and longfin tuna fishing is good. Point
title: BLUES, FLUKE AND BONITO AVAILABLE

body: The United States Open has come to Queens, a carnival with Lacoste shirts. There are bright yellow and white tents, and little pavilions hung with philodendrons, and stands that offer commemorative T-shirts and hardcover editions of the life stories of Billie Jean King, Bjorn Borg, even Ilie Nastase. There is lots to eat, much of it fashionable
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; THE INVISIBLE PEOPLE OF THE UNITED STATES OPEN

body: I f your favorite streams are so low that trout sulk in the tepid water, making only occasional after-dark and early-morning forays for food, you might enliven your days with pickerel. One advantage of fishing for pickerel in the Northeast is that they are ubiquitous in shallow ponds and lakes and sometimes they also thrive in the shallows of large
title: PICKEREL PLENTIFUL IN NORTHEAST

body: Law-enforcement officials disclosed yesterday that Nathan Masselli, the slain son of a Federal witness, had been an undercover informant for Leon Silverman, special prosecutor in the investigation of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan. The officials said Mr. Masselli had secretly cooperated with Mr. Silverman's office in its investigation of
title: SLAIN MAN HAD ROLE IN INQUIRY

body: Taste is largely a matter of habit, and for almost four generations of Brooklynites, preferences for cakes, pies and pastries were to a large extent shaped by the buttery miracles turned out by the Ebinger Baking Company. By the time that family-run chain went bankrupt in 1972, there were 67 bright and gleaming Ebinger's bakeshops in Brooklyn,
title: DE GUSTIBUS; A BROOKLYN BAKERY ADDS NEW LUSTER TO EBINGER'S NAME

body: I f your budget or your occupation doesn't allow for much traveling and you sometimes envy those who are chasing Atlantic salmon in Iceland one week and tarpon in Costa Rica the next, a change of angling goals and equipment may be in order. One way to stave off this unhappy state is to go after fish that are plentiful with the lightest tackle
title: OUTDOORS; LIGHT TACKLE HAS ADVANTAGES

body: Dozens of detectives and other investigators are working virtually round the clock to analyze physical evidence and to trace the movements of five women killed in an unusual series of strangulations in lower Manhattan and Brooklyn. While some detectives sought to identify the latest victim, whose unclothed body was found Tuesday in the Narrows off
title: POLICE CONDUCT INTENSE SEARCH IN 5 STRANGLINGS

body: 1 Margate, N.J.: Day and night angling for large bluefish continues 15 to 16 miles offshore. Atlantic bonito and albacore showing. Small bluefish taken close to beach; good angling for weakfish in inlets on flood tides. Barnegat, N.J.: Offshore bluefishing good day and night; many bonito 12 miles offshore; big weakfish taken by commercial netters
title: Blues, Fluke, Flounder Plentiful

body: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I. A puff of wind catches the small sail and, like a kite starting its flight, the sailboard begins to glide across Manhasset Bay. ''You've got it, but you forgot something!'' Neil McConnell, the instructor, yells from the beach. ''You have to smile. If you are too serious, you have to fall in and start all over.'' So I smiled,
title: OUTDOORS

body: Baseball Baseball: Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 161st Street and River Avenue, Bronx. (Television - Channel 11, Radio, WABC, 770 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Padres at San Diego. (Television - Channel 9, 10 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570 10 P.M. Cardinals vs. Astros at St. Louis. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.) Boxing Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini,
title: Saturday Sports

body: F rom the Atlantic Ocean at Montauk to the Adirondacks and the mighty St. Lawrence River, New York State offers a variety of camping that is unmatched in the Northeast. Camping is an infinitely varied endeavor. At the extremes are those who luxuriate in trailer homes hooked up to water and electricity at a well-developed area, and those who tuck a
title: OUTDOORS; STATE OFFERS VARIETY OF CAMP FACILITIES

body: As far back as anyone can remember, the elderly people have come out of their small apartments and their old houses to sit on park benches throughout the city in the heat of summer, and they still do. It may well be the ultimate urban scene. They sit along many of the roadways, such as Shore Parkway in Brooklyn and near the White Plains Road subway
title: CITY PARKS STILL COAX OUT THE ELDERLY

body: A recent dispute over the appointment of a principal for a Brooklyn elementary school has focused attention on the process of selecting local school administrators under the city's decentralized school system. The naming of Kathleen Shay, a 34-year-old administrator of a remedial-school program, to be principal of Public School 193 in the Midwood
title: PARENTS' ROLE IN HIRING OF PRINCIPAL DISPUTED

body: A lthough negotiating turbulent rapids in canoe, raft or kayak gets most of the attention on television and in print, one should not forget the pleasures offered by quiet waters. The canoe is the ideal craft for moving along a lake or river with a minimum of intrusion upon the natural scene. A canoe is a highly portable, versatile craft that is at
title: No Headline

body: WHEN the Main Street Theater closed its doors last March after the first of the season's four scheduled performances, the board of directors decided not to dissolve the financially strapped theater but to make an attempt to rescue it. And while the board has yet to commission the feasibility study it says it needs to gauge the county's future
title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL

body: Three men were attacked and one of them was beaten to death when their car stalled on a street in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning. The victims, who were on their way home from work, were black, and the police said the attack was unprovoked and ''racially motivated.'' They said the victims were assaulted at 12:10 A.M. by a
title: BLACK MAN IS KILLED BY MOB IN BROOKLYN: ATTACK CALLED RACIAL

body: International A major Israeli offensive led by planes and tanks began in Lebanon in an apparent effort to drive Syrian and Palestinian forces from the Beirut-Damascus highway. Israeli jets and artillery also bombarded Palestinian camps and residential areas in Beirut. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Israel announced a new cease-fire after several hours of
title: NEWS SUMMARY; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 23, 1982

body: A former police officer has been convicted of the June 1981 strangulation of a 27-year-old securities analyst after a six-day trial in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. The ex-officer, 37-year-old Arnold Kane, faces 25 years to life in prison when he comes before Justice Martin Schneier on June 28 for sentencing in the killing of the analyst, Joan
title: BROOKLYN JURY FINDS AN EX-POLICE OFFICER GUILTY OF '81 MURDER

body: MAY will arrive this weekend in a blaze of cherry blossoms in Brooklyn, on the strings of wild kites in Central Park and in the sounds, smells and sights of festivals and tours all over town. This is the weekend when New Yorkers and their suburban neighbors take to the outdoors. What follows are some of the ways in which you can participate. An
title: HOW TO GO A-MAYING: A GUIDE FOR THE CITY AND SUBURBS

body: Thomas Clohessy, 21 years old, of 270 Ovington Avenue, Brooklyn, and Angelo Ditre, 23, of 193 Chestnut Avenue, Staten Island, were arrested yesterday and charged with the $150,000 robbery of the Daily News printing plant in Brooklyn on Feb. 20. The police recovered $24,000. Mr. Clohessy was a security guard at the plant at the time of the robbery.
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: ''WE'RE used to it, that's all,'' said 16-year-old Alla Roytberg. ''I guess, to many of us, it's completely ordinary, like television.'' ''Among some adults, there's fear of it, I suppose,'' said Brett D'Ambrosio, who recently turned 15. ''It's the fear of the unknown. It's a natural fear, but there's really nothing to be afraid of.'' ''I've heard
title: 'COMPUTER KIDS' MASTER SKILLS AS BASIC FOR THEM AS READING

body: The greeting card was delivered to the gym at about the same time that the Brooklyn College basketball players began their Wednesday afternoon practice. It wished the players well and talked of how their success in reaching tonight's Final Four of the Division III National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs had ''united'' the school. ''When
title: A Final-Four Team Grown in Brooklyn

body: By way of honoring the day's festivities, John Meehan of Manhattan points out a Hibernian curiosity. ''Among the myriad bank advertisements in New York newspapers for Individual Retirement Accounts,'' he reports, ''only those in that excellent publication, the weekly Irish Echo, spell the words out, rather than use those catchy initials: I.R.A.''
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: MORE than 175 million pounds of fish pass each year through the barnlike structures of the Fulton Fish Market in Manhattan, making it the largest central clearing house for fish in the country. According to an official of the Fishery Council, the public relations arm of the market, most of this fish is consumed within the New York metropolitan
title: A CONSUMER'S GUIDE TO FRESH FISH

body: MORE than 175 million pounds of fish pass each year through the barnlike structures of the Fulton Fish Market in Manhattan, making it the largest central clearing house for fish in the country. According to an official of the Fishery Council, the public relations arm of the market, most of this fish is consumed within the New York metropolitan
title: A CONSUMER'S GUIDE TO FRESH FISH

body: The players took some strange detours before the nation's highestscoring college basketball team was assembled on the northwest corner of Flatbush and DeKalb Avenues -in the old Brooklyn Paramount Theater, where the biggest motion pictures played and Frank Sinatra sang in person. A few cases of homesickness, a player and a coach unable to get along
title: THEY CAME HOME TO L.I.U.

body: A 34-year-old man suspected of having committed about 50 robberies in physicians' and dentists' offices since October shot himself to death in his Brooklyn motel room early yesterday when he saw the police closing in. Detectives said that the suspect, Robert Scheff of Brooklyn, had held up professional offices in Brooklyn and Queens, robbing
title: HOLDUP SUSPECT IS A SUICIDE AS POLICE CLOSE IN

body: A Brooklyn jury yesterday visited a rooftop from which the 8-yearold son of a Hasidic rabbi was thrown to his death, then returned to court and quickly found the defendant guilty of murder. The defendant, Lawrence Gordon, who was a security guard in the apartment complex where the boy was killed, could get up to 25 years in prison when he is
title: MAN GUILTY IN SLAYING OF CHILD

body: A coach at a Brooklyn high school believes his athletes are forging doctors' signatures on the preseason medical examinations required by state law, a coach in Manhattan characterizes the physicals provided in city health clinics as ''garbage,'' and a Board of Education official says the current system of screening young athletes in New York City
title: MEDICAL CARE HELD INADEQUATE FOR ATHLETES IN CITY'S SCHOOLS

body: On a June afternoon in 1913, when an army of schoolboys dressed in white shirts and dark knickerbockers demonstrated their physical skills at a Central Park extravaganza, Theodore Roosevelt clapped youngsters on the back with cries of ''Bully!'' and congratulated the Public Schools Athletic League for ''making these boys good young Americans.''
title: CITY'S PUBLIC SCHOOL ATHLETICS ERODED BY YEARS OF CUTBACKS

body: Ray Haskins has at times been accused of breaking the tradition among coaches of not trying to run up the score against opponents. Haskins is the coach of Alexander Hamilton High School, the Public Schools Athle tic League defending basketball champion. Last Wednesdaynight, his te am defeated Sheepshead Bay, 179-61, in its regular season finale .
title: The Issue of Too Many Points

body: Dave Peletier of Brooklyn's Wingate High School set a meet record of 49.2 seconds in the 400-meter dash and later anchored Wingate's 1,600-meter relay team to victory at the West Point invitation meet today. Trevor Graham of Brooklyn's Sheepshead Bay High set a meet record of 1 minute 5.47 seconds in the 500-meter run when he beat Charles Jenkins
title: Brooklyn Schoolboy Excels in Track Meet

body: A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth was arrested yesterday at 2:30 P.M. for robbing a private home at 2314 63d Street in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst section. The police said the suspect, Edwin Velez of 2391 Bedford Avenue, would be charged with ''numerous'' crimes against the elderly in the Bensonhurst, Flatbush and Sheepshead Bay areas. ... Two armed men held
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: In a short story called ''Only the Dead Know Brooklyn,'' Thomas Wolfe looked down his nose at the long blocks of two-family houses and wondered how any individual thought could develop in such a uniform atmosphere. Whatever Wolfe may have imagined, a great deal of creativity has come out of Brooklyn's neighborhoods over the years. Additional proof
title: LIBRARY CAMPAIGN EVOKES FONDNESS

body: More than a year ago, Abraham Newman risked his life to aid a woman in trouble. He has been paying for it ever since. Mr. Newman, then 83 years old, was walking on the boardwalk at Brighton Beach in Brooklyn on Oct. 16, 1980, when he tried to help a woman who was being assaulted by a young man. The assailant grabbed Mr. Newman's cane, beat him and
title: MAN, 83, WHO HELPED CRIME VICTIM IS REFUSED MONETARY AWARD BY CITY

body: The innocent bystander who was killed in what was apparently a gangland attack on two men in Brooklyn Monday night was described yesterday as a social worker who had devoted her life to helping others. The bystander, Veronica Zuraw, 53 years old, was killed in her kitchen by a shotgun blast that penetrated the second-floor door and walls of he r
title: BYSTANDER KILLED IN MOB SHOOTING WAS A SOCIAL WORKER AND EX-NUN
